The map of Western Palestine was constructed from surveys conducted by C. R. Conder and H. H. Kitchener on behalf of the Palestine Exploration Fund between 1872 and 1878 (the last map was surveyed in 1878). The maps were drawn by Conder and Kitchener but the lettering and finishing was done mostly by J. Brophy and J. Maling of the Royal Engineers. The Albright copy is one of the subscriber's copies, no. 75, but the name of the original subscriber has not been preserved. There is a key map at the front of the volume. The map sheets are numbered I-XXVI, but are not titled.
The library also holds the later 1897 edition (MAPS 2-1897).
One of the missing sheets (XXI [Nablous]) may be one of the 2 duplicate sheets from the 1897 binder.

The sheets are untitled, but titles have been added in manuscript. Sheets in the order of binding: I [Tyre] -- II [Banias] -- III [Acre] -- IV [Safed] -- V [Haifa] -- VI [Tiberias] -- VII [Caesarea] -- VIII [Jenin] -- IX [Beisan] -- X [Kfar Saba] -- XII [Tubas] -- XIII [Jaffa] -- XIV [Shiloh] -- XV [Akrabeh] -- XVI [Ashdod] -- XVII [Jerusalem] -- XVIII [Jericho] -- XIX [Gaza] -- XX [Beit Gibrin] -- XXI [Hebron] -- XXII [Ein Gedi] -- XXIII [Wady Ghuzzrh] -- XIV [Beer Sheba] -- XV [Tel Arad] -- XVI [Masada].
Will require conservation work before use.
Library also has a digitized version of this map on CD (GA1321.H6 2004).
1 map on 26 sheets, bound in 1 vol. ;

The map of Western Palestine was constructed from surveys conducted by C.R. Conder and H.H. Kitchener on behalf of the Palestine Exploration Fund between 1872 and 1878 (the last map was surveyed in 1878). The maps were drawn by Conder and Kitchener but the lettering and finishing was done mostly by J. Brophy and J. Maling of the Royal Engineers.

The library holds the original 1880 copy (MAPS 2-1880). The 1897 edition is a later edition, with the addition of Schumacher's name as the surveyor of the areas east of the Jordan. The plates which include these geographical areas have been altered, but for the most part the map plates in this edition are reprints of the earlier, 1880, edition.
One of the 2 duplicate sheets (XXI [Nablous]) may be the missing sheet from the 1880 binder.

The sheets are untitled, but titles have been added in manuscript. This map is in 3 sections. The sheets have been cut close and glued together in such a way that most of the sheet numbers are not visible. Ordnance Survey of the Peninsula of Sinai.
2 vols. (of 5) : Text - [4], 324 p., 12 col. pl., 8 monochrome pl. Maps - 10 folded maps

The ordnance survey of the Sinai peninsula consists of one volume of text [44], with a separate album of 10 folded maps [45]. The text volume includes 20 (12 col., 8 monochrome) numbered lithographed plates of views, antiquities, diagrams, and zoological and geological specimens. Several plates depict details from the monastery of St. Katharine. The survey was originally published in 5 volumes, with 3 volumes of more than 150 mounted photographs, which the library does not hold.

The ordnance survey of Jerusalem was conducted under the direction of Sir Henry James, Director of the Survey. The survey was done mostly by Captain Charles W. Wilson of the Royal Engineers.

Title page reads: 'Ordnance Survey of Jerusalem Made with the Sanction of the Right Hon: Earl de Grey and Ripon, Secretary of State for War, by Captain Charles W. Wilson, R.E. under the direction of Colonel Sir Henry James, R.E. F.R.S. &c. Director of the Ordnance Survey. Published by Authority of the Lords Commissioners of Her Majesty's Treasury.'
The work consists of three parts, bound separately: the text (v.1[46]), the album of maps (v.2[47]) and the album of photographs (v.3[48]).

From cover: 'A map of Palestine from surveys conducted for the Committee of the Palestine Exploration Fund and other sources ... Engraved and printed for the Committee at Stanford's Geographical Establishment.'

Map of Palestine showing streams water courses, wells, aqueducts, mosques, watch towers, trig stations, roads and tracks with topographical and geographical terms in English and Arabic. Relief shown by hachures, shading and spot heights.
In lower margin of each sheet: P.E.F. Palestine.

Present are sheets 1-16, 20-23 (untitled). These sheets were intended to form one large map of at least 1000 x 880 cm., but since three sheets are missing we cannot supply exact dimensions. There is an earlier edition dated 1890, in 21 sheets, but the 1900 edition is extremely rare. The Albright library has two copies, both of which lack sheets 17-19. Copy 1 is bound, with 2 copies of sheet 13. Copy 2 is loose-leaf, with 2 copies of sheet 21; it is also missing sheets 6,9,10,15.

The sheets are untitled, but titles have been added in manuscript in copy 2. Sheets: 1. [title] -- 2. [Beirut]--3. [Damascus] -- 4. [Jebel el Kaus] -- 5. [copyright & scale information] -- 6. [Haifa] -- 7. [Kuneitra] -- 8. [Kenath Nobah] -- 9. [Jaffa] -- 10. [Nablus] -- 11. [Rabbath Ammon]-- 12. [Salekah] -- 13. [Gaza] -- 14. [Jerusalem] -- 15. [Bezer] -- 16. [Topographical & geographical terms] -- 20. [Kadesh Barnea] -- 21. [Bozrah] -- 22. [Kul'at el Garahy] -- 23. [Explanation, Key map].

The survey of Western Palestine : Jerusalem.
Committee of the Palestine Exploration Fund,

The atlas to The Survey of Western Palestine: Jerusalem, 1884, by Col. Sir Charles Warren and Capt. Claude Reignier Conder. Contains 49 detailed plans and illustrations of Jerusalem which have been linen-backed. The only two maps in the atlas form plates 48 and 49.

Plate 1. Title--Plates 2-3. Plan of Jerusalem showing Rock Contours--Plates 4-5. Masjed Al Aksa, or Haram Ash Sharif...excavations--Plates 6-7. Haram Ash Sharif (the Noble Sanctuary), shewing rock contours--Plates 8-9. Sections on plates II and III--Plates 10-11-12. Sections on plates IV and V--Plate 13. Elevation of North-East Angle 1:120--Plate 14. Elevation of Wall of Noble Sanctuary 1:60--Plate 15. Sections... Wall of Noble Sanctuary at North-East Angle--Plate 16. Birket Israil--Plate 17. Details near North-East Angle, Noble Sanctuary--Plate 18. Details... at South-East Angle--Plate 19. Elevation of East Wall, South-East Angle--Plate 20. Elevation, South-East Angle, South side 1:120--Plate 21-22-23. Painted Marks on East Wall, full size--Plate 24. Single Gate and Ophel Wall--Plate 25. The Triple Gate and Double Tunnel--Plate 26. Elevation of South Front--Plate 27. South-West Angle, South Front--Plate 28. Elevation of Robinson's Arch, South-West Angle, West Side--Plate 29. Plan of Portion of Arcade Excavation [Robinson's Arch]-

Plate 30. Plan of Aqueduct [Robinson's Arch]--Plate 31. Plan and Section...Passage at Barclay's Gate--Plate 32. Elevation... of Barclay's Gate--Plate 33. Section through Causeway Vaults and Wilson's Arch--Plate 34. Section and Elevation of Vaults... West Wall at Causeway--Plate 35. Plan of Secret Passage in Causeway--Plate 36. Plan of Great Causeway--Plate 37. The Twin Tunnel near North-West Angle--Plate 38. Details South-West Angle, Noble Sanctuary--Plate 39. Researches inside the Noble Sanctuary--Plate 40. The Wall of Ophel 1:120--Plate 41. Excavations at the Bishops School [Details about the City]--Plate 42. Acqueduct, Virgin's Fountain--Plate 43. Passage, Virgin's Fountain [and other details]--Plate 45-46-47. Pottery found in Excavations--Plate 48. Reconnaissance Jordan Valley--Plate 49. Reconnaissance of the Plain of Philistia--Plate 50. Plan and sections of the Muristan (by Captain Conder, R.E.).
The Albright library also has a facsimile edition, 1998, DS102.P18 Vol.4.

Carte du Liban d'après les reconnaissances de la Brigade topographique du Corps expéditionnaire de Syrie en 1860-1861, dressée au Dépôt de la Guerre par le Capitaine d'État-Major Gelis sous le ministère de S. E. le Maréchal Comte Randon.
92 x 70 cm. on sheet 108 x 66 cm.
This map may be connected with the massacres in Syria and Lebanon in the 1860s.
May require conservation work before use.
Reviewed in: Annales de Géographie, vol. 23-24, no.131, 1914, p. 335336:

'Pour l'uvre topographique du Corps expéditionnaire de Syrie, voir : C. Maunoir, Rapport sur la carte du Liban publiée par le Dépôt de la Guerre (B. S G., 5* sér., IV, 1862, p. 263-269). Si les chemins de fer ont été mis au courant, à la date de 1913, on n'a pas modifié le «Tableau statistique indiquant la population des Districts du Liban» qui figure dans le coin inférieur droit de la feuille. Le Nouveau Dictionnaire de géographie universelle de Vivien de Saint-Martin (III, Paris, 1887, p. 346) qualifiait ces chiffres d' «évidemment exagérés». Rien n'est moins « évident ». Ils concordent, pour l'effectif des principales confessions religieuses (Maronites, Grecs orthodoxes, Druses) avec ceux de N. Verney et G. Dambmann (p. 28-29 de l'ouvrage analysé dans Xe Bibl. 1900, n°514). -- L. Raveneau.' http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/geo_0003-4010_1914_bib_23_131_19144

Nouvelle Carte generale des provinces asiatiques de l'Empire Ottoman (sans l'Arabie) /
dressée par Henri Kiepert, Berlin 1883; Dietrich Reimer, éditeur, 1884.
96 x 155.5 cm. on sheet 104 x 165 cm.

The map is gauzed and folded with printed paper wrappers mounted on the first and last segments. The date 1884 is on the map surface, but this copy may have been reissued later since the date 'XI.98' appears on the lower right hand corner of the printed wrapper. This very interesting map is based on information supplied by both scholar-travellers and engineers working for the various railways being constructed at the time in Asia Minor and Palestine. Kiepert specifically refers to Messrs Purser, Pressel and Briot, working for English, Austrian and Ottoman companies respectively, to Mr. Humann of Smyrna, and to the scholar Ramsay, well known for his many expeditions in Asia Minor, to Benndorf, Niemann, and Petersen, to Hartmann and Wunsch, and to the expedition he himself made in 1870.
For further information about this map, see also http://cartomed.mmsh.univ-aix.fr/notices_EN/N08.html
Will require conservation work before use.

The map is a reproduction of a hand drawn map made by Wilhelm Berg.
The map is in two parts: Teil I: Nile from Aswan to the Mediterranean--Teil II: Wad Medani [Blue Nile] via Khartoum to Aswan.
Each of the two parts is accompanied by a key map and an index.
Part I consists of: index (p. 3-50), key map, 26 sheets: I - XVIII, XVIIIa, XIX - XXI, XXIa, XXII - XXIV.
Part II consists of: index (p. 51-76), key map, 23 sheets: II - VIII, X - XI, XIII - XXI, XXIII - XXVII. Sheets I, IX, XII, XXII of pt. 2 were never printed.
Each sheet is 30 x 21 cm. in size.
